abstractText: Anti-hyperlipidaemic effect of chloroform fraction of aerial parts of Zygophyllum indicum (Fagonia indica Burm.f.) was studied in rats. Adult Wistar albino rats were distributed into five groups. Rats of all groups except group I were given an intraperitoneal injection (Triton X-100) to induce hyperlipidaemia. Groups (I and II) served as normal and hyperlipidaemic control groups respectively. Group III and group IV were administered with 250 and 500 mg/kg chloroform fraction of the plant respectively after 18 h of inducing hyperlipidemia. Group V was given 10 mg/kg of the standard atorvastatin. Chloroform fraction had significant (p<0.05) hypolipidaemic effects on lipid profile and biochemical parameters with a protective effect on the liver in comparison to group II. F. indica with hypolipidaemic effect is useful in the management of hyperlipidemia. Chloroform fraction with its constituents can be used as an antihyperlipidaemic supplement in developing countries for the development of novel therapeutic agents.

sections.heading: Experimental
sections.text:
Plant Collection, its identification, and authentication
F. indica with aerial parts was collected from the Cholistan Desert of Bahawalpur, Pakistan. Taxonomist Prof. Dr. Zaheer-ud-din Khan, Department of Botany, GC University Lahore, Pakistan, identified and authenticated this plant. A voucher specimen with no. GC-Herb-Bot. 2967 was submitted to Dr. Sultan Ahmad Herbarium of the same university. After being collected, aerial parts of the plant were washed, dried in the shade at room temperature, and ground into a coarse powder using an electric grinder before being stored.

sections.heading: Extraction
sections.text: Powdered plant material was macerated using the cold maceration method in a variety of solvents, including n-hexane, chloroform, methanol, and finally water, in increasing order of polarity, sequentially with periodic shaking. Filter paper (Whatman No. 1) was used to filter the extracts. A dark brown material was obtained by evaporating methanol filtrate in a rotating vacuum evaporator (Heidolph Lab 4002, Germany) under reduced pressure of 50 oC. The aqueous extract was dried in a freeze drier (Christ, Germany).

sections.heading: Fractionation (Liquid-liquid partition)
sections.text: The methanol extract (80g) having the most hypoglycemic effect as we already investigated the activity (Rehman et al. 2019) was fractionated with the solvent n-hexane which was further fractioned with chloroform then with ethyl acetate, and the last with n-butanol, in increasing order of polarity. Four fractions were separated using a separating funnel. Dry fractions of nhexane (HF), chloroform (CF), ethyl acetate (EA), and n-butanol (BF) were obtained. The fractions were stored in closed glass containers after being evaporated under a vacuum in a rotary vacuum evaporator at 40 oC.

sections.heading: Chemicals and reagents
sections.text:
Analytical-grade chemicals and reagents were used during the study. The chemicals that were used in the investigation were purchased from the company (Sigma-Aldrich St. Luis, Mo, USA). The Starch was taken from Sigma Life Science (Walt, MA, USA) Triton X-100 (SigmaAldrich, St. Louis, MO, USA) was purchased from Bayer (AG Wuppertal, Germany) along with acarbose (Glucobay®) from UNI-CHEM-chemical reagents, China. Assay kits for ROCHE diagnostics (Roche, USA), ethanol, formalin, water, hematoxylin, paraffin, and eosin stain were purchased from the market. For the analysis of biochemical, Roche Diagnostics kits
COBAS C 111 (ROCHE) cholesterol enzyme kits, Alanine Transaminase Reagent, Triglyceride Reagent, and Aspartate Aminotransferase Reagent.

sections.heading: Phytochemical screening
sections.text: Chloroform fraction of F.indica was subjected to qualitative phytochemical screening to check the presence or absence of alkaloids, carbohydrate, saponins, lipids, glycosides, tannins, phenols, triterpenes and phytosterols following the standard methods (Trease and Evan 2007).

sections.heading: Experimental animals
sections.text:
The animal ethical committee (AEC) granted approval for each and every animal experimentation operation (approval number AEC/PUCP/1076, dated 03/05/2018). Throughout the study, adult Wistar albino rats having weights between 180–220 g were used. The rats were kept in a ventilated animal transit room with a controlled temperature range (22– 25 °C), relative humidity (50–7%), and a cycle of 12 hours of light and 12 hours of darkness for one week. Rats were acclimated to the laboratory condition before the start of the experiment in the PUCP animal house, in Lahore, Pakistan. Throughout the study, the rats had unlimited access to water and food.
Acute toxicity studies Toxicological studies for chloroform fraction were determined as per
OECD (Organization for Economic Co-operation Development) guidelines No. 425 (OECD 2008). It was found to be safe up to 1000 mg/kg b. w. when administered orally.
In vivo antihyperlipidaemic effects of Fagonia indica
The chloroform fraction of Fagonia indica was assessed for in vivo hypolipidaemic effects by Triton X-100-induced hyperlipidaemic model followed by Gundamaraju et al. 2014.

sections.heading: Induction of hyperlipidemia
sections.text:
In order to develop hyperlipidaemia the standard pellet diet in dry form was mixed with egg yolks and butter and was given by oral route daily to five groups except for group I. After fasting for eighteen hours overnight, an intraperitoneal (i.p) injection (0.01%) of Triton X-100 (100 mg/kg b.w.) in physiological saline (0.9% NaCl solution) was given to all the groups except the normal control group I (Gundamaraju et al. 2014).
Animal study design
A total number of 30 healthy rats weighing between 180-220 g were employed for the study. The rats were distributed into 5 groups of 6 rats each. All the groups except group I were injected with Triton X-100 by the i.p. route. Atorvastatin was given as a common reference
drug. The normal pellet diet was given to the first group (negative control) orally along with water and 10% of dimethyl sulphoxide (DMSO). After 72 hours of Triton X-100 injection, group II serving as hyperlipidaemic control (positive control) was given a daily dose of 10% DMSO for one week. Chloroform fraction of F. indica was given to group III and group IV every day at the doses of 250 and 500 mg/kg respectively with 10% DMSO for one week after inducing hyperlipidemia. The chloroform fraction was given to the rats by oral route by the use of a stomach tube having a disposable syringe. The fifth group was treated as a reference and was administered with atorvastatin (10mg/kg) orally as a standard drug. All the rats with hyperlipidemia were given a daily dose of 10% DMSO for one week. The rats had free access to water and food.

sections.heading: Collection of blood
sections.text:
Finally, a direct cardiac puncture was done under mild inhaled chloroform anesthesia to collect blood samples into activator tubes having gel clots to separate serum and allowed to clot at room temperature for 4 h. In order to prepare the serum, centrifugation of blood was done for 5 minutes at 3000 rpm (Aftab et al. 2022). The prepared serum was then kept at -20 oC and utilized for the investigation of different biochemical parameters. For histological studies, a piece from the liver and aorta was cut, preserved in 10% formalin, and kept at -20 oC
Determination of lipid profile in serum
Using the appropriate assay kits for the Chemistry Analyser Cobas C111 (Roche Diagnostic, Roche, USA), the analysis of serum samples was carried out to estimate total cholesterol-TC, triglycerides-TG, and HDL-C.

sections.heading: Assay procedure:
sections.text:
The serum sample was put into RD standard Cobas sample tube (false bottom tube) and inserted in a chemistry analyser (Cobas C111). The specific test was selected in the main menu and the measurements were taken. LDL-C, VLDL-C, and Atherogenic Index (AI) were determined as follows:
LDL-C = TC - HDLC - VLDL – C (Friedewald et al. 1972).
VLDL-C = Triglycerides/5 (Munshi et al. 2014).
AI = TC-HDL-C/HDL-C (Harnafi et al. 2008).

sections.heading: Determination of liver enzymes
sections.text: AST-aspartate aminotransferase, ALT-alanine aminotransferase, and ALP-alkaline phosphatase were determined in serum using a Chemistry Analyser (Cobas C 111) of Roche Diagnostic (Friedewald et al. 1972).

sections.heading: Antioxidant activity
sections.text: MOD, SAD, and CAT were not investigated for the investigation of antioxidant activity which has already been determined for this plant (Rehman et al. 2019)

sections.heading: Histopathological studies
sections.text:
Rats were killed so that the liver and aorta tissues could be removed for histopathological analysis. The tissues were cleansed in regular saline. The tissues were placed in 10% formalin and kept at -20 oC for histological analysis. For dehydration, the tissues were immersed for 12 hours in ethanol of higher concentrations (50–100%). The samples were cleaned twice for three hours in Xylene. At 58 oC, paraffin wax embedding took place for six hours. After that, blocks were prepared using steel moulds. The blocks were embedded with paraffin and the sections were cut at 4-6 um thickness by the use of standard microtome. After, tissues were divided into 5 L using a microtome and floated on a hot water bath, where the temperature was kept at 45 oC. The portions were placed on spotless glass slides and kept in an incubator for three hours at 37 oC to promote additional adherence. The tissues were stained with Eosin and Hematoxylin stains (Abdelgadir et al. 2020)
Staining technique
The sections were de-paraffinized, placed on the glass slide, then rehydrated, and finally stained with Hematoxylin for 20 minutes and Eosin for 10 minutes (Abdelgadir et al. 2020). The slides were cleaned with Xylene. After coverslip, the slides were analysed using a light microscope (Olympus Corp., Tokyo, Japan).

sections.heading: Statistical analysis
sections.text:
Data were expressed as mean ± SD of three readings. One-way and two-way ANOVA was applied for statistical analysis using GraphPad Prism version 5 followed by a post hoc test (Tukey’s Multiple Comparison test). The difference between the groups was considered to be significant (P < 0.05) statistically.

Figure S1. The pictures of slides (Haematoxylin and Eosin (H and E) × 100) of rats of normal, hyperlipidaemic, and treated groups administered with chloroform fraction of Fagonia indica and the standard atorvastatin. The group I slide demonstrated the normal architecture of lobular and hepatocyte cells. On the other hand, Group II (which only received Triton X-100) has demonstrated congestion, periportal lymphoblast infiltration, and central inflammation. The liver had extensive granular degeneration, fatty infiltration, and hepatic blood vessel congestion. It was observed that the cytoplasmic vacuoles in liver cells were enlarging (arrows of different colours). Groups III and IV treated with chloroform fraction had modest cytoplasmic fatty infiltration, granular degeneration, and mild to moderate hepatic blood vessel congestion (orange and white arrows). Group V treated with atorvastatin showed minor inflammation of the centrizonal regions and normal lobule morphology. Hepatocytes with fatty alterations that included cytoplasmic granular degeneration and fatty infiltration.
Figure S2. The pictures of slides (Haematoxylin and Eosin (H and E) × 100) of rats of normal, hyperlipidaemic control, and treated groups with chloroform fraction of Fagonia indica and the standard atorvastatin. Group I showed normal aortic configuration; The media, tunic intima, and adventitia of the normal group's aorta slice had normal histology, according to light microscopy. Endothelial cells formed a continuous layer in the intima. Group II showed lipid particle accumulation (black and red arrows). Group III (250 mg/kg) and Group IV (500 mg/kg of chloroform fraction had droplet vacuoles of lipids. When compared to normal control rats, the aorta of Group II rats had severe lipidemic conditions, such as lipid particle buildup and significant blood vessel congestion (group I). Group IV, which received treatment with plant aerial parts, displayed minor blood vessel congestion but not a lipidemic state. No sign of lipid droplets building up, and practically typical.
